div.p: 1. IV:45 Sunday

I walked to the Capitol, and heard Mr Cookman, the chaplain of the Senate. An English Methodist; settled here within the last two years, and celebrated for his eloquence. His text was from 1. Timothy 4.16.— First clause of the verse “Take Heed unto Thyself” which words he pronounced with a loud voice—a deep emphasis upon each of the underscored-words and a semicolon pause between each of them and the next. He then began by some general remarks upon the characteristic of the present age—which he said was excitement—association—movement in masses—the power of numbers—which he exemplified by alluding to the multitudes of Meetings, of Conventions of Societies for Political, Religious or benevolent purposes— But he was now about to address his auditory individually, in a solitary capacity; and in the words of the Apostle Paul, to say to each man, woman and child who heard him Take—Heed—unto Thyself.— What an easy, natural, beautiful introduction! He made no formal division of his subject; but it divided itself; and he had the skeleton always in his head— First guarding against any imagination that his object was to inculcate selfishness, but only the spirit of that self-love, which is implied in the precept to love thy neighbour as thyself—he successively repeated Take heed what thou thinkest—what thou sayest—what thou doest with obvious considerations of the relative importance of thoughts, words and actions—upon each of which he descanted at considerable extent— Then still repeating the Instruction take heed to thyself, applied it to the several relations with others, he finished with words of exhortation, particularly addressed the younger part of his hearers— Hast thou ever done a good action? I hope thou hast—many—what thinkest thou of them now? do they not afford thee an inexhaustible source of pleasure? Hast thou never sinned? I know thou hast—what thinkest thou of that sin now?— I will tell thee what thou thinkest—with regret—with regret! if not with remorse—thy habitual thought is—I wish I had not committed that sin— Oh think then that on thyself depends whether thy destiny after this life shall be an eternity of blessedness or of woe.— Then after a somewhat over-charged and hyperbolical declamation upon eternal punishment; he closed with saying Oh! think of that dying admonition of a pious father—think of that angel voice of a beloved sister, urging thee to virtue—and Take—Heed unto Thyself!— He closed, and the tears were streaming down my cheeks— I left a card at the lodgings of the Speaker Mr Hunter—and one next door for Mr T. H. Sumpter. I saw Mr John Campbell, and at Mrs Corcoran’s Jos. L. Tillinghast and Governor Lincoln— Met R. Peters, in the street; who promised to send me C. P. Van Ness’s argument before the US. Supreme Court in the Holmes case.— T. B. J. Frye dined with us— After dinner at the Presbyterian Church I heard Mr Wood, from Genesis 32.10. “And Abraham stretched forth his hand, and took the knife, to slay his son.” The sacrifice of Abraham— The principle of obedience to the Will of God— I read the Article in the last December number of the Southern Literary Messenger, upon James Smithson— And part of the Instructions to the Antarctic expedition in the London and Edinburgh Philosophical Magazine, Septr. 1839—
2. V. Monday.

Miss Elizabeth Pierce was here this morning with a Letter informing her that the Committee of Revolutionary claims of the House had determined to report favourably in part upon their petition— But with this she was not satisfied, and was exceedingly anxious to obtain the whole of their claim, and yet unable to make it intelligible to me— My time straitened me to attend a Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures, and I was there at ten O’Clock— No Quorum— Mitchell, Davis and Eastman attended, and at a quarter past 11. adjourned till Thursday— 5 minutes after, Dromgoole attended, and would have made a Quorum— The irksomeness of attending Committees is almost universal, and throws upon the Chairman all the burden of the Committee’s labours— In the house it was the regular day, for the reception of Petitions; but the Speaker decided, that the Resolution offered by Casey to refer to the Committee of Ways and Means a Memorial praying an appropriation for the continuance of the Cumberland Road through the States of Ohio, Indiana and Illinois, with Instructions to the Committee to report a Bill, had preference over the presentation of Petitions— From this decision Governor Lincoln appealed; but it was sustained by the House. It was unquestionably wrong; and annuls a proviso incorporated into the rules upon an amendment offered by me—that No debate should be held on any petition upon the day when presented, nor upon any other day assigned by the house for the presentation of petitions—my amendment had hitherto been of some avail— It is now annulled— And the vote of the House was carried not upon the merits of the rule; but for the effect that it would have had to displace the Cumberland Road, on the order of business so that it could not have been resumed perhaps for Months. And thus another shackle is fixed upon the right of Petition— Not one was presented this day— Mr Bell of Tennessee had the floor since the suspension of the debate on this subject last week— He spoke upwards of three hours in answer to Pickens, Crary, and Howard of Indiana; and his object was to prove the duplicity of the administration party with regard to the policy of appropriating money for internal improvements. Little interest was taken in his argument and the house thinned off as he spoke till there was little more than a Quorum left—when he finished Casey proposed to modify his Instructions to the Committee of Ways and Means to leave discretionary with them the amount of the appropriation to be made for the continuance of the road— Other members, and among them Rhett of South-Carolina manifested a wish to be heard and at 4. O’Clock, the House voted by Tellers to adjourn— I am yet reading the Article on the Instructions of the Royal Society to Captain Ross’s Antarctic expedition, upon the manner of making magnetical observations.
3. V.30 Tuesday.

Mr Patton, a Mathematical Instrument maker, came this morning to enquire about the renting of Mary’s dwelling house North of the President’s Square, where we dwelt from December 1829 till November 1838, or rather till the precedingof July when I last left it.— Mr T. B. Johnson resided in it last Winter and until May—since which it has been untenanted.— I referred Mr Patton to Mr Frye, who is the agent of Mrs John Adams and manager of all her affairs— Mr Patton makes mathematical instruments for the Government and professes to make them equal in perfection to any that can be procured from any other part of the world— He was born and brought up in Baltimore—but resided for the last 25 years at New-York— He has lately come by advice of Coll. Abert and of the chief engineer to live at Washington, and intends permanently to settle here— As he went out a Stone-cutter named Richard Donovan came in with a Petition signed by himself andothers praying for payment of wages during the time that the works on the public buildings from April to June 1838. There are several Documents annexed to the Petition to sustain the claim— The Petitioners are all Irishmen, and complain that the allowance for the suspended time was made to others and denied to them. Donovan took his Petition with him to shew it to Governor Lincoln, chairman of the Committee on the public buildings—but he brought it back afterwards, and left it with me to be presented to the House— I went to the Pension Office, and left with the commissioner two Letters from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn L. I with documents to support claims for Pensions of Mrs Troup and of Sarah Lennington— I met Mr Frye, who told me that Mr Patton had been with him to Mary’s house on the Square, and had offered for it 500 dollars a year rent; and he thought of accepting it—the house now lying empty because he had demanded 600 dollars, and he could find no tenant who would give so much— At the House, the Resolution from the Committee of Commerce, for having engraved a chart of some part of the Southern coast was debated nearly an hour— Habersham of Georgia made a Speech to prove that it was more important to the Mariners of Maine than to the Planters of Georgia—

After much foolish wrangling the previous question was carried, and the Resolution, for printing the map was rejected upon a plea of economy; by yeas and nays 84 to 95.— Two or three more reports only were received when J. W. Jones called for the orders of the day, and the Bill to continue the Office of Commissioner of Pensions, and for transferring to him the Navy Pension fund, from the Secretary of the Navy. The motion to reduce the Salary of the Commissioner from 3000 to 2500 dollars was carried, and the Bill passed— Then the red river raft Bill, and speeches of R. Biddle, and J. Pope— Adjourned after 4. O’Clock— In the Evening a Mr Mann was here with a subscription book for Hazard’s United States Register, which I signed.
4. V. Wednesday.

Going this morning to the Pension Office, with a Letter from Messrs. Lewis and Pierce to the Commissioner, and a Letter from Jonathan Trumbull Governor of Connecticut dated September 1776. in support of the pension claim of Mrs Phebe Reeve, I met opposite to the President’s House Mr Doty and another member of the house, who enquired if I was going to see the Commissioner of Pensions and upon my answering yes they said I should find the doors of the Office closed, and no one there— The Law constituting the Office of Commissioner of Pensions expired yesterday; and that by which it is continued, and the Navy-Pension fund is transferred to the Commissioner only passed the House of Representatives yesterday, and did not get through the Senate till this day. So they closed the Office— On my way thence to the Capitol I stop’d at Mr Pettrich’s Studio, and saw his statues and busts— His fishing girl in marble and his young hunter companion in clay— He said General Keim had purchased them for 2000 dollars each; and a bust of Mr Van Buren for 500 dollars.— He had also busts of H. Clay, Forsyth Poinsett, and Amos Kendall— A cast of the Bust of W. W. Seaton— Colossal Statues of Washington, of St. Joseph and other Saints for a Roman Catholic Church at Emmetsburg, and Busts of himself, his wife, and seven children— He shewed me a small piece of the marble from the newly opened Quarry near Frederick much finer than a piece of Carrara marble compared with it— At the House— Campbell Chairman of the Committee of Elections was ready to report, but the turn of that Committee was past— Petrikin offered a Resolution, instructing the Committee on Accounts to investigate the contracts for stationary made by Hugh A. Garland, the Clerk of the House with Langtree. Objection was made by Charles Ogle in retaliation for Petrikin’s perpetual objections to resolutions offered by others—but the objection was withdrawn—his Resolution was received, and Charles Johnston offered as an amendment the Resolution which he had repeatedly before, in vain attempted to get before the house. It could not now be parried and Johnston sustained it by a strong Speech— Then Petrikin modified his Resolution to Johnston’s acceptance, and by the call of the previous question it was carried.— Campbell made a second effort to produce his Report, but the vote on his motion to suspend the rules was 104 to 79. not two thirds.— Vanderpoel, offered a string of Resolutions parceling out the President’s Message, among the standing Committees— In answer to an enquiry from me he said it was his express purpose to keep it out of the Committee of the whole on the Union— The vote on his motion to suspend was 104 to 85. and then at the motion of Mr Lawrence the Message was referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Reports from Committee, were received till past 4. Adjourned—
5. V. Thursday.
Fire in my chamber after 3 days intermission—

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures. Present Adams, Slade, Worthington, Davis, Mitchell, Dromgoole, Tillinghast— The hour of meeting is 10. A.M— It was a quarter past 11 before a Quorum was formed and two of the members came in just before Noon when the Committee must adjourn to attend the House— I asked the instructions of the Committee what report to make to the house upon the memorial praying for a repeal of the exemption from duty of pins, and was answered with talk— The Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury recommending a reduction of the drawback upon refined sugar; and pickled fish, with the accompanying documents was discussed, and a motion was made that the Chairman be instructed to report a Bill to reduce the drawback— But the whole subject was postponed.— At the House, after an ineffectual attempt by Chinn to get the rules suspended for a motion respecting the transportation of the Mail, and another by J. W. Jones, to make the Treasury Note Bill the order of the day for to-morrow, both of which failed for lack of a majority of two thirds, the call of the Committees for Reports was continued and at last concluded— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures, the bill to ensure more effectively the collection of the Revenue, which was read twice by its title—referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and ordered to be printed— I moved that it should be made the special order of the day for the third Wednesday in March; but the house refused.— I presented also from the Committee on the Smithsonian bequest Bill an amended Bill, with the Report which I had prepared, and sundry documents, including the Messages ofDecember 1835 and of 6. and 7. December 1838. and my Report ofJanuary 1836— Also an Estimate of the expense of erecting and establishing an astronomical observatory— I stated also that a member of the Committee Dixon H. Lewis would prepare a minority report, which the Committee proposed should also be printed, together with the Memorial of Charles Lewis Fleischman presented at the last Session of Congress and then printed— James Monroe proposed that 5000 extra-copies of my report should be printed, but the Speaker said it was not now in order—and No, was heard from several voices— I am convinced that nothing good can be done upon this subject by this Congress— As Night came on the Call of all the Committees, standing and select having gone through, the Speaker called again upon the Committee of Elections, and Campbell presented his Report on the New-Jersey contest, which was read— Petrikin immediately moved that the five spurious members from New-Jersey should be sworn in and the previous question. A Scene of disorder and confusion ensued—a decision of the Speaker that Fillmore was entitled to the floor, reversed by a vote of 82 to 88. and a strange jumble of votes upon successive motions to adjourn, till one shortly before 9 in the Evening succeeded— I took no part in the snarl— Debate it could not be called.— I rode home.
6. V. Friday

I went this morning to the Capitol with a heavy heart, expecting that Petrikin’s Resolution to swear in the five false claimants to their Seats, would be forced through by the Previous Question with out waiting for the evidence to come, reading that which has been received, or hearing the commissioned members on their claim— I had resolved, if thus called, not to answer to my name— Many of the members had determined to do the same, and if all the minority would do so, the majority could not form a quorum of the House and therefore could not perpetrate this outrage upon all Justice, and all Law— I found there were so many Southern members afraid to hazard this experiment that it cannot be carried effectively into execution— I resolved however at all events to practice it myself, and await the consequences— I found soon after the reading of the Journal, that there was some flinching also on the administation side— The whole party could not be brought to the point of taking the question now without a word of discussion upon the report of the Committee— Briggs offered a Resolution to postpone the consideration of the report, until the time fixed by the Committee for the return of the parties with their evidence.— But this Resolution was only read for information; Petrikin not having withdrawn his motion for the Previous question— Rives offered a Resolution to make the subject the special order of the day for next Tuesday at 12 O’Clock, and every successive day till finally disposed of— Upon some remonstrance he modified the resolution to commence at one O’Clock instead of 12.— The morning hour expired, and the orders of the day were called—being for private business.— The Speaker then said that before proceeding to the orders of the day, he would present to the house a packet addressed to him, received last Night, and containing testimony concerning the New Jersey election— And now commenced a new debate, which immediately ran into points of order, and consumed the time of the house till 5. O’Clock, when the house adjourned in the midst of the debate, without reaching the orders of the day; without touching a particle of private business, and without even disposing of the packet presented by the Speaker.— Fillmore was speaking on a motion of reconsideration— Petrikin called him to order— The Speaker decided that he was in order. Petrikin appealed, and Holleman moved to lay the appeal on the table— The Speaker decided that this laid the whole subject, and of course Fillmore’s motion upon the table, and took the floor from Fillmore— From this decision he appealed and remonstrated with great vehemence against it as abridging his freedom of Speech— The Speaker found two precedents against his decision; one in 1834, and one of his own.— And at this point came the adjournment— I called at Gadsbys and saw Mrs Lawrence— Mr Lawrence and his daughter sick. Miss Cutts dined with us.
7 IV:15 Saturday—

I called this morning at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury, and left with him the Letter from Mr Henry Lunt to his son, the Revd William P. Lunt, the Declaration of Henry Lunt, and the certificate of Moses Davenport, to sustain a claim to a portion of the prize money deposited in the Treasury for the captures of the squadron of Paul Jones in 1779. upon which Mr Woodbury promised to have enquiry and report made.— I spoke to him also of the Letter from Jesse A. Hoyt Collector of New-York, which he had sent me remonstrating against one of the amendments adopted by the Committee of Manufactures to his Bill— I said that the Committee had not intended what Mr Hoyt supposed would be a necessary consequence of the amendment; and I should myself be willing to strike it out.— My next call was at the Pension Office where I found the Commissioner James L. Edwards re-installed, and with whom I left a Letter from Lewis and Pierce to him and an enclosed Letter from Jonathan Trumbull Governor of Connecticut to Coll. Christopher Leffingwell of 15 September 1776. to sustain the Pension claim of Phebe Reeve— Also a Letter from James Phelps and Sarah his wife, concerning his Pension-claim. On my way to the Capitol I stop’d at Gadsby’s and enquired how Mr and Miss Lawrence were— Mr Lawrence no better. Miss Lawrence a little better— At the House the whole day was consumed in disentangling the snarl in which the New-Jersey election case was left last Evening.— The Speaker’s last revised decision was that the laying of Petrikin’s appeal on the table, did not take the floor from Fillmore on his motion to reconsider the vote referring the packet of testimony from New-Jersey to the Committee of Elections— From this decision an appeal was taken, and the decision was sustained 85 to 83. whereupon Duncan took a second Appeal from the same decision, upon the ground that Petrikin having moved the Previous Question upon this motion to swear in the spurious New Jersey claimants, Fillmore’s motion to reconsider was not in order and ought not to have been entertained by the Speaker— But this decision was again sustained by 99 to 89.— And the floor was thus at last restored to Fillmore— He then called for the reading of the packet received by the Speaker— To which the most vehement resistance was made—but the Speaker decided that they should be read, and they dared not appeal from the decision— They were depositions proving that the South Amboy election was not lawfully held, and named about twenty unnaturalized Irish workmen, whose votes for the Van Buren Candidates were challenged yet received— Fillmore made some remarks upon the strange and self contradictory report of the Committee and of the manner in which it was palmed upon the House—which exasperated Medill, so that he too told a story of what had passed in Committee, and trumped up a base charge against Truman Smith of his holding secret intercourse with the commissioned members, which he discovered by secret intercourse with the other party— Campbell endeavoured to make Peace by declaring that the conduct of every member of the Committee had been fair and honourable— Turney called the previous question on Fillmore’s motion for reconsideration, which was rejected. Then alternate motions to call the house and to adjourn, till near 8 O’Clock when the adjournment was carried.
8. V:30 Sunday

There was a notice in the newspapers, that the discourse in the Hall of the House of Representatives this day would be on Christian courtesy— That it was specially intended for members of Congress, and that young men who chose to attend were therefore requested to take seats in the circular gallery.— The singularity of this notice was not unobserved; and there were those who thought it not inoffensive— I thought it quite unnecessary for its ostensible purpose; but I accepted it as an invitation of attendance to members of Congress— Dr Bates was the preacher and his text was 1. Corinthians 13.4. [“]Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not: Charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up— 5. Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil.” Dr Bates had read the whole of that incomparable chapter the amplified exposition of the Sermon upon the mount and the quintessence of the Christian system as regards this world— Dr Bates began with a preliminary Dissertation upon Self love and disinterested benevolence—and he pointed out the obvious distinction between self-love, and selfishness.— Then he analysed the several properties positive and negative attributed in the text to Charity—spoke something about the practice of duelling, and the code of honour, and without making any direct application to members of Congress, indirectly exhorted them under the name of Christian courtesy to long-suffering and kindness, and cautioned them against vain boasting and self conceit, unseemly behaviour, captiousness and evil thinking—all which was proper, just, and seasonable; but there were not twenty members of Congress to hear it— Not more than two thirds of the Seats were filled, and, of those that were filled were occupied chiefly by women— My attention was perhaps too much diverted by a tall elderly gentleman, very neatly dressed with a florid complexion somewhat bald and wool white hair, who came in with two young ladies; one of them very beautiful and took seats almost facing mine— Mr Grainger with whom I walked home after the service with his daughter, told me that the Gentleman was Mr Griffin, an eminent lawyer of New-York, and one of the young Ladies his daughter and the other, the beauty, Miss Stanton daughter of Daniel Stanton, a merchant of that city.— I called at Gadsby’s and was informed at the Bar that Miss Lawrence was better, but her father not so— I visited Mr John Read whom I found again at his chamber confined with a relapse of fever and ague— His fellow lodger Mr John Taliaferro was with him— My next call was on Mr Webster, who was sore afflicted with a Catarrh, something like my own— While I was there Mr Griffin and Miss Stanton came in to visit Mrs Edward Curtis who came down to them— Thomas B. J. Frye, who has just received his Doctor’s Diploma, dined with us— After dinner at the Presbyterian Church Mr Wood preached from Acts 4:13. “Now when they saw the boldness of Peter and perceived that they were unlearned and ignorant men they marvelled; and they took knowledge of them, that they had been with Jesus”
9. IV:45. Monday

Last evening MrMellen of Boston came and passed two hours with me in conversation, boiling over with abolitionism— He wrote to me some weeks since; and enquired if he could obtain the use of the Hall of the House of Representatives to deliver a Lecture disclosing the physical causes of the differences in the colour of the human race— I answered him that the use of the Hall would certainly not be granted for any such purpose; and that in this climate the very proposal if known would stamp him as an abolitionist— From his talk this Evening there would be no mistake in the conclusion— This morning I was at the Capitol at 10 O’Clock to attend the meeting of the Committee of Manufactures, but only three other members of the Committee appeared, Tillinghast, Slade and Eastman and there was no Quorum.— Absent Dromgoole, Nisbett Worthington, Mitchell, and Davis— The use of the Hall from 10 till Noon had been granted, for an exhibition of the blind; and was so occupied, but I could not attend it— Mr Bell had offered a Resolution to direct the Secretary of War to suspend the execution of an Article in a Treaty with the Winebago Indians— It had passed without opposition or notice— Bell had come to me, and asked if I thought it improper to use the word directed as applied to the Secretary of War, and whether requested would be better— I had till then not noticed the resolution; but when he read it to me I said that neither directed nor requested was a suitable word; the House could neither direct nor request the head of an executive department to suspend the execution of a Treaty; and I would move a reconsideration of the Resolution— He said he would ask leave to modify it— He did so—and I moved the reconsideration. This was on Saturday, but my motion was not entered upon the Journal. I therefore again moved the reconsideration this morning— Bell asked leave to modify it to a mere declaration of expediency which was done by general consent.— The day was consumed in receiving Resolutions; the Speaker beginning with Kentucky, where he had left off this day fortnight, going Northward to Maine, and then backward to Ohio, and the States which had then been called.— My call on the Secretary of the Treasury for a report of State Stocks purchased was passed; but at the sound of the call on the President for the Amistad correspondence, up started the mobocracy and objected— I then offered a Resolution of call upon the Secretary of War, concerning the employment of the blood hounds— Linn Boyd instantly called for the yeas and nays on the question of consideration— Turney told him it must be on the passage of the Resolution, and he moved accordingly— The Resolution was thus received, which I had not expected— I said if the yeas and nays were to be taken, I should wish to assign in a few words my reasons for offering the Resolution, and it was laid over of course— They will never take it up— I offered a resolution also referring the claim of Charles Larrabee to the Committee of Invalid Pensions—adjourned at 5. O’Clock— Miss Cutts was here; and in the Evening Mr Bliss a Chronometer maker from New York.
10. V.30. Tuesday.

I received last Evening a Letter dated 14. Feby 1840. from Daniel Brent Consul of the United States at Paris with enclosures, two Letters to Lloyd N. Rogers of Baltimore, the first of 28 Jany. announcing that Mrs. Catherine Kortwright Hay had died the day before after an illness of about 3. weeks—the second giving an account of her funeral— Of his having taken possession of her effects with the consent of the French Government, and of the state of her affairs and debts—and a copy of her will made at Baltimore in September 1837. by which she constituted me and Richard M. Smith of this City, her Executors and left all her property to her 3. Granddaughters children of Lloyd N. Rogers by her daughter, just before then deceased. I called on Richard M. Smith, at the Bank of the Metropolis of which he is Cashier, and left the papers with him— On my way to the Capitol I stop’d at Gadsby’s where I learnt that Mr Lawrence and his daughter were both better.— At the House after the reading of part of the Journal, and frequent motions to suspend the reading of the numerous resolutions that were offered, which were for some time resisted by Proffit of Indiana a motion was at last made to suspend the rules and supersede the further reading of the Journal which was carried— Then Petrikin’s amendment and previous question came up— Botts a member of the Committee of Elections presented a minority report; and asked for its reception—objection was made— Botts moved a suspension of the rules to admit the report—the vote was 116 to 80 to suspend, but there not being two thirds the report was excluded.— The second to the previous question taken by tellers wastothe previous question was carried, by yeas and naystoupon the main question. I did not answer at the call of my name— Two others only of the opposition did the same James Monroe asked to be excused from voting on consciencious scruples, and was excused— Hunt offered a resolution that I should be compelled to vote— Then he modified to include the other two, and then came back to the call upon me alone, which the Speaker decided to be in order but his decision was reversedtoPetrikin’s amendment and proviso were divided and two separate questions were taken— Botts then offered his minority report again—but objections arose, and confusion, and an adjournment was carried shortly after 3. A Mr Sherwood from Fishkill landing— Also Mr A Brisbane of New-York, who took back his volume upon agricultural Association, which he thinks a grand idea— Dr Channing’s Son William F. and a Mr. G. G. Channing paid morning visits, and Mr Webster came, while I was at the Capitol. I was deeply afflicted at the event of this day; and pray for self-possession and resignation.
11. V:15. Wednesday.

Wasted the morning in assorting and filing Letters and papers; and in reading Newspapers and a pamphlet by Greley Hannaford, entitled The Herald of the glorious morning of Emanuel, and Genius of Universal Emancipation— At the House, Mr Fillmore gave me a written authority from Mr Hiland Hall of Vermont, to occupy his Seat, during his absence which will be for about a fortnight.— He left the City this morning, and his seat is a very good one. Mr Wise was in his seat again this day, after an absence of nearly a Month sick; and for the last fortnight at Philadelphia— After the reading of the Journal the Speaker called for Reports from the Committee of Elections; and Mr Campbell presented his supplementary report on the New-Jersey case, with the Journal of the proceedings of the Committee and the Testimony upon which their prior report was made up—but not the Depositions last received and referred to the Committee—and the report closed with a report that the reported papers should be printed— Rice Garland moved that the depositions last received and referred to the Committee should also be printed— Petrikin objected that this was not in order, because the papers were in the possession of the Committee and not of the House. Garland modified his amendment two or three times but Petrikin always met him with a point of order, and Dromgoole threatened the Speaker with an appeal from his decision if it should be in Garland’s favour— Garland noticed the insolence of this menace of a party majority; and the Speaker coolly suggested to Garland the form in which his motion would be in order. Garland said he was indifferent as to the form, of his motion, and Dromgoole with his brandy-brazened face consoled himself with a boast that on the point of order he had been right— A debate then followed, venomous as a rattlesnake between Rives and Medill on one side and Fillmore and Truman Smith and Crabbe on the other, which was cut short by the expiration of the hour and the call for the orders of the day. Biddle’s instructions to the Committee of Ways and means, with the Senate’s red river raft Bill were adopted by yeas and nays. 136 toa prognostication of the fate of the Bill and of all internal improvement Bills in this Congress— The Sub-Treasury Bill was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means after an abortive attempt to refer it to the Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union; and another by Horace Everett, with an addition proposed by me, and which he accepted to give instructions to the Committee— Wise made a hectoring speech, defying the administration to pass a Sub-treasury Bill, for which he said he would vote, if they would— But this Bill was not a sub-treasury, but a Government Bank— Adjourned about half past 4. After the adjournment I went into the Clerk’s Office, and assorted the papers to be printed with the amended Smithsonian bequest Bill reported by order of the Committee— Returning home I stop’d at Gadsby’s to enquire of Mr and Miss Lawrence. She is better; but Mr Grainger told me Mr Lawrence had a regular bilious fever.
12. V. Thursday

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Nisbett, Slade, Mitchell, Tillinghast, Worthington, Dromgoole— Absent Eastman— After some discussion, the Chairman was directed to report Petrikin’s Bill to repeal the act of 14 July 1832. exempting rail-road iron from duty, without amendment; the members of the Committee being free to support the Bill or oppose it as each one may think proper. The Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, recommending a reduction of the drawback on exported sugar, and pickled fish, was thoroughly discussed without coming to a conclusion— The Letters remonstrating, against the amendment of the Committee to Hoyt’s Bill, requiring the Appraisers to examine every package of imported goods were considered, and it was agreed unanimously with the exception of Dromgoole that the Chairman should move to strike out the words— Dromgoole whose only object is to defeat all action of the Committee favourable to the manufactures, the trickery of points of order, which he and his party so shamelessly practice in the house, has made repeated attempts to introduce into the Committee— He pretended that because the Bill had been reported to the House the Committee had nothing more to do with it; and could not instruct their Chairman to propose an amendment to it— He said it was the Lex Parliamentaria, but no other member of the Committee supported him— The Resolution offered by Worthington, to report a Bill reducing the drawback on exported fine sugar to 3 cents a pound from 5 was taken up— Tillinghast moved an amendment to repeal the exemption of pins from duty; but this was rejected by the Committee— The drawback on pickled fish was found to be in the form of a bounty— Question arose whether its reduction could be included in the same Bill, with the reduction of the drawback on sugar, and the whole subject was postponed— In the House, Jenifer had the floor on the second Report from the Committee of Elections, but he made little progress; the morning hour being consumed in bitter altercation in the form of explanations between Fillmore, Medill, Truman Smith, Botts and Campbell the Chairman of the Committee Campbell.— The lie, and rascality were freely circulated among the parties— Jones, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means parted them by calling for the orders of the day.— Bell’s Bill for securing the freedom of elections was first in order but he consented to pass it over, on condition that it should not lose its place on the Calendar, that the Treasury Note Bill might be immediately brought up— This, Mr John W. Jones, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means introduced with a dull and feeble speech of about half an hour; when Cushing opened a Battery upon the Bill and upon the administration till a quarter past 4. when without concluding he yielded the floor for a motion to adjourn which was carried— I dined with Mr James K. Paulding, Secretary of the Navy. Messrs. H. Clay, Southard and Webster, Barnard, Bell, Biddle, Dawson, Hoffman, Grinnell, Grainger, Kemble, and Wise, of the Senate and House were there, with sundry others— Home at 10.
13. IV:45 Friday.

Rather an uneasy Night with admonitions to beware of the house of feasting.— I was awake between 3 and 4 this morning, and a dispersion of Spirits disabled me for writing beyond the journal of yesterday— At the House Jenifer occupied again the floor upon the New-Jersey election case, and exposed the falsehood of the Report of the Committee and the prevarication of the majority of the Committee who made it— The subterfuges and evasions to suppress the testimony which falsifies the conclusion of the report are heart-sickening. A Supplement to the National Intelligencer of this Morning contains an Address to the People of the United States signed by Millard Fillmore, Trueman Smith; George W. Crabb and John M. Botts the Minority of the Committee; and their Report which the majority of the House have suppressed, by refusing the order that it should be printed— At the close of the hour John W. Jones called for the orders of the day; and feebly asked that the consideration of the Treasury Note Bill should be taken up: but did not call for the yeas and nays, and his motion to suspend the rules was rejected. Vanderpoel said to me yesterday that as no appropriations had yet been made, he saw no reason for hurrying the Treasury Note Bill— The true reason of their delay is to wait for the reinforcement of their five recruits from New-Jersey. The House went into Committee of the wholeDavee in the Chair, and took up the private Bills reported by the Committee of Claims—among them was the Bill for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell, which was laid aside to be reported to the House without opposition or remark— As I had no charge of any other of the Bills which could come up this day I availed myself of the opportunity to go into the Library to look up some information respecting the use of blood hounds— Mr Wise had taken out of the Library, Dallas’s History of the Maroon War in Jamaica in two 8vo. Volumes, which he yesterday put into my hands, I to be responsible for returning them to the Library.— I found there the 32d. volume of Hansard’s Parliamentary debates p. 922, the debate upon Genl M’Leod’s motion in the House of Common’s on the 21st. of March 1796.— The most distinguished Speakers in this debate were Dundas and Sheridan. Dundas apologetical, and promising to prohibit the use of the dogs—on the faith of which Genl M’Leod withdrew his motion.— I found also a History of the Maroon War; at the close of the first volume of Bryan Edwards’s History of the West Indies— Genl M’Leod in his Speech read an extract from Robertson’s history of America referring to the works of Las Casas concerning the use of blood hounds against the indians by the Spaniards in that age.— I have still to consult Robertson, and Las Casas— On returning to the house just after the Clock struck 4. I found the members coming out, the house having just adjourned. The Committee had been obliged to rise upon finding itself without a Quorum— Returning home I stop’d at Gadsby’s to enquire of the state of Mr Lawrence and his daughter— She is convalescent, but he has a very threatening bilious fever, and the bar-keeper told me that Mrs Lawrence was taken ill this morning.— Evening too drowsy for work.
14. VI:45 Saturday.

A Man by the name of Lee came this morning with an engraved Portrait of General William Henry Harrison, the whig candidate for the succession to the Presidency at the next election, price three dollars— Then, while we were at dinner came a man named Adams, with a Bible arranged in Chronological order, in two volumes large octavo fourteen dollars—both of which emplettes I declined. At the House the first hour was occupied again by Jenifer in examining reviewing and dissecting the report of the Committee of Elections, and the gross inconsistency of the majority of the House and of the Committee in their proceedings— Neither the report of the Committee, nor their journal, nor one particle of the testimony has yet been printed. Not a word of the testimony against the illegal returns rejected by the Governor and Council of New-Jersey was even considered by the Committee.— They gave the parties time to take their testimony till the secondin April— Six weeks before that time the house pass a resolution instructing them to report forthwith, which set of the candidates had a majority of the lawful votes of the People of New-Jersey, and they report forthwith that the noncommissioned claimants have a majority of lawful votes, with an argument proving that whether the majority was of lawful votes or not depends entirely upon evidence yet to come, and for the procurement of which the Committee had given the parties time till the second week in April.— In this state of things, evidence is received by the house, proving the illegality of the Southampton election, in the face of which, under the screw of the previous question, the house pass a Resolution directing the Speaker to swear in the non-commissioned members as having the majority of the lawful votes, without waiting for further evidence, and without ever having heard the parties.— Jenifer has probed this state of the proceedings till the majority of the Committee writhed in agony— At the expiration of the hour this day, Jenifer was drawing to a conclusion, when the orders of the day were called. Rives intreated that the house would suffer the debate to proceed and moved a suspension of the rules which was lost— He then asked as a favour to be permitted to make a personal explanation.— Not allowed— He then imploringly appealed to his party, and asked if he had not a friend who would move to suspend the rules that he might make his explanation— Botts did then make the motion The yeas and nays were called and the motion was carried 130 to 32.— I voted in the negative— Rives then made a rambling bullying ridiculous speech of an hour till after repeated calls to order he was obliged to take his seat with a face as sheepish as it had been wolfish when he began— The day was wasted and the house adjourned— I went and passed an hour in the library and came home— Stop’d at Gadsby’s— Lawrences all better.
15. V:30. Sunday.

When I commence this morning with reading, I lose the precious hours for writing and they are never retrieved. This morning I finished the reading of an Article in Hunt’s Merchants Magazine for March 1840. upon the principles of credit, by my Son Charles— It was first intended for a Lecture before the Mercantile Library Association at New-York; but thinking it on reflection too long and too abstract, he took another subject for the Lecture, and published this in the Magazine— I read also the Introduction to the Second Edition of judge William Jay’s View of the Action of the federal Government in behalf of Slavery— I borrowed at the Congress Library yesterday a Volume containing a tract in French, printed at Antwerp in 1579. and being a translation by Jacques de Miggrode of the Memoir by Las Casas, Bishop of Chiapa upon the Tyranny and cruelties perpetrated by the Spaniards in the West Indies, among which page 15 was the employment of blood hounds trained to tear to pieces and devour the Indians of Hispaniola— I walked this morning to the Capitol, with the expectation of hearing Mr Cookman preach— Mr Joseph Blunt whom I met opposite Gadsby’s American Hotel walked with me, and we overtook Mr. Granger and his daughter The Hall was well filled but not crowded, and all the galleries were nearly empty— And instead of Mr Cookman, the preacher was a young man named Emery, just out of College— His text was from James 1.5— [“]If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God;” and his sermon though methodistical was eloquent and well delivered— After the service I paid visits to Messrs. Botts, Stanly, L. Williams, Stanly—Wise and Proffit, all of whom I saw, and to Messrs. Dawson, Waddy Thompson, Jenifer and King of Georgia, for whom I left cards at their lodgings— I met Dr Sewall and enquired how the Lawrence family were. They are all sick, but with prospects of recovery. I called to see Mr John Reed who is yet confined to the house at his lodgings; but he was at dinner.

Afternoon I attended at St. John’s Church, and heard the evening service read for the second Sunday in Lent; and a Sermon by Mr Peter Chauncey son of the late Commodore Isaac Chauncey; from Psalm 46:10. first part of the verse “Be still, and know that I am God.”— Mr Chauncey is a very young man and promises well as a preacher— His discourse seemed to be intended for consolation to the afflicted. I found Mr Griffin in my pew, the use of which I had offered him last Sunday. Going to Church I met Miss Cutts with Miss Causten whom she introduced to me. Evening visit from Mrs Tudor, with her Son Henry, whom I had not seen before— He has been here about three weeks and is to leave the City to return to Boston to-morrow.
16. VI. Monday.

I found this morning in the collection of the works of Las Casas the original treatise in Spanish upon the cruelties of the Spaniards in the New world of which the French book which I had previously consulted was a translation, and the detail of horrors in it staggers my belief.— On my way to the Capitol I stop’d at Mr Force’s Office and borrowed of him Robertson’s History of America, and a Translation of Muñoz’s History of the New World— Mr Force had just sent me a copy of a proclamation of John Penn Governor of Pennsylvania of 7. July 1764. offering a reward for Indian Scalps. Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Mitchell, Slade, Tillinghast and Eastman—a bare quorum, formed after I had been waiting little short of an hour— Absent Dromgoole, Nisbet, Davis and Worthington— I prevailed upon the Committee to take up read and consider ten petitions for levying a duty upon silks; upon which I said I was desirous of making a report to the House, and of receiving the instructions of the Committee upon what principles to make it— After some discussion the subject was postponed.—Two Petitions from Chester Co. praying for the revision of the Tariff, and a Temperance Petition from Walworth N.Y were read. I was directed to report a motion that the Committee be discharged from the further consideration of them and that the latter should be referred to the military and naval Committees and to the Ways and means— In the House, the pretenders from New-Jersey Dickinson, Vroom, Cooper, Ryall and Kille, appeared, were sworn by the Speaker, and took Seats— Jenifer moved to postpone their qualification till the second week in April that the commissioned members might be heard— The Speaker decided this motion not in order— There was a call for the credentials of the counterfeits— The Speaker said there was a Resolution of the House that they should be sworn, which superseded the necessity of their producing credentials, and they were sworn— It was petition day— The several questions of instructions to the Committee of the Ways and Means of the petition from Illinois for appropriations to the continuance of the Cumberland road, were under a motion for the previous question— There was a call of the house 192 members answered, and further proceedings superseded— Marvin’s amendment was rejected— Pickens withdrew his, and Casey’s Instructions were rejected— Then the Speaker began the call for Petitions at the Territory of Iowa, and proceeded Southward and Northward till he came to New-York, during the call of which a Petition presented by D. D. Barnard, which the Speaker decided to be within the rule, and from which decision I took an appeal, brought an adjournment at 5. O’Clock; much to the annoyance of the members from New-York.
17. IV:30 Tuesday.

I received a message from the Globe Office, requesting me to call there this morning which I did, after first visiting the pension office, and leaving there a pension certificate, in favour of Mehitabel Clark of Masonville, Delaware County, New-York, with a claim from her for its increase, and two depositions in support of the claim— At the Globe Office, the foreman wanted directions for the printing of the report on the Smithsonian bequest Bill, which I gave him— He said he would send me the first proof sheet of the Report to-morrow morning— I bespoke 100 copies of the report, without the appendix, for which they would charge me, Rives said 2 dollars— At the House, a motion was made to suspend the rules to enable the members from the States which were not called yesterday, to present petitions, but it was lost 8 to 7. John Reed was allowed to report two Bills from the naval Committee having been absent from indisposition when the Committees were called— Jenifer then concluded his speech, upon the motion for printing the Journal and papers on the New-Jersey-election case— Jenifer convicted the majority and Chairman of the Committee of the grossest and most glaring inconsistency, in which the majority of the house is equally involved— I never knew a contested election decided upon any principle of justice, nor did I ever know a case in which Justice was set at such open and shameless defiance as in this. Jenifer was succeeded by A. J. Brown of Tennessee a member of the majority of the Committee, who had spoken only a few minutes when the hour expired, and the orders of the day were called— The house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union W. C. Dawson in the Chair— Cushing, in an hour and a half concluded the Speech which he had commenced last Thursday, upon the general policy of the administration, and its errors—a very sensible and eloquent Speech, but not bearing upon the bill before the Committee, against which there is no real opposition— Mr King of Georgia took the floor, when Cushing finished; and it being a quarter past three moved an adjournment which was carried— I went into the library, and consulted Buffon and Goldsmith on the natural history of the dog—and Spanish Dictionaries for the word Lepreles which I could not find— Governor Lincoln who watched with Mr Abbot Lawrence last Night told me that he had been fearfully ill in the Night with the bilious colic— The bar-keeper at Gadsby’s told me that he was relieved from that attack, and was better.— Mr Lloyd N. Rogers, and Mr Richard N. Smith visited me this morning, with reference to Mrs Hay’s Will. Mr Rogers produced a sealed paper, which at his request I opened, and which was another Will of Mrs Hay dated 22. May 1837. The copy transmitted from Paris by D. Brent was datedDecember 1837.

Mr Rogers in producing the sealed paper, which he requested me to open, said it was a Will of date subsequent to that, the copy of which had been transmitted to me, by Mr Daniel Brent from Paris— It was folded up like a Letter, sealed with black wax, with a Seal which Mr Rogers said I should know, and which I took for a Seal, which had been used by Mrs Hay’s father—President James Monroe, and was superscribed in the hand-writing of Mrs Hay— A Will of Elizabeth M. Kortwright Hay, left with Lloyd N. Rogers Esqr.— The Will was entirely in the hand writing of Mr Rogers, excepting the day and month of the date, the signature of Mrs Hay, and of the three witnesses, all which were in pale ink, and other hand writing than the body of the Will— The day and Month had evidently been left in blank in the draught previously made, and filled up at the time of execution, but the date of the year in the hand writing of Mr Rogers, and written at full length was one thousand eight hundred and thirty seven.— Mr Rogers said that was a mistake—that the execution of the will was in 1838. just before Mrs Hay embarked for France; that he Rogers had written the will copied verbatim from a draught in her own hand writing—that the first signing witness was a magistrate; and the two others young men lodgers at the same house where she then boarded at Baltimore, and that with the Will, Mrs Hay gave him a beautiful cameo, which had been given to her by the Pope— By this will Mr Rogers is made sole-Executor—all her property,—real, personal and mixed is given to his three daughters, by her daughter, Hortensia; and to the survivor of them if either of them should die in minority, and Mr Rogers is authorised to make the distribution of it between them at his discretion— No residuary bequest to Mrs Gouverneur, nor any notice taken of her— I said that after this disclosure, I should in no event undertake to act as an Executor, though I should cheerfully give any counsel or advice that might be useful to any of the parties interested in either of the Wills— We agreed that the mistake in the date of the year, in the Will produced by Mr Rogers must be rectified in the Maryland Court of Chancery, where both Wills must be exhibited, in a suit to which Samuel L. Gouverneur and his wife must be made parties. But that this cannot be done until the original Will, executed at Richmond 7. December 1837. shall have been received from Mr. Brent at Paris— I mentioned these circumstances to James Monroe in confidence at the House— He said Mrs Hay had told him immediately before she embarked for France, that she had made her sister Gouverneur her residuary legatee—
18. V. Wednesday.

William Browne was here this morning to make an arrangement for the note which he gave me on the 16th. of May 1829.— Which arrangement consists in a promise to give me a new note with the same endorser.— I received from the Globe Office the first sheet proof of my report on the Smithsonian bequest Bill—and found on revising it, no less a blunder than President Jackson’s Message of 17. Decr. 1835 printed twice— I took it to the Office and shewed it to the foreman who said it must be printed over again— Afterwards he sent a messenger up to the house for a copy of my Resolutions presented to the joint Committee on the 6th. of Feby 1839. and adopted by the House Committee on the 13th. of the same Month— I was obliged to have a copy of them made from the manuscript journal of the last year’s Committees, by Mr Berry of the Clerk’s Office, which I sent to the Globe Office; and in the Evening, I received a second proof sheet of my report which I revised. At the House Aaron V. Brown of Tennessee a member of the Committee of Elections occupied the morning hour, in a laborious, abortive effort to defend the majority of the Committee against the charges of Jenifer— Neither the Majority of the Committee nor the House can be defended for their conduct in this case— To this day there has been neither authentic evidence nor hearing of the parties before the house, and the Committee after they had given time to the parties to take testimony till the second Monday in April, by order of the house reported that the spurious claimants had a majority of the lawful votes, when the very purpose for which they had given time to the parties to take testimony was to ascertain that fact— The conduct of the majority of the House in this case from beginning to end has been governed by Will, and not by judgment; and so I fear it will always be in every case of contested election— I never knew it otherwise.— Mr Brown’s argument was moderate and decorous in manner, but at once over confident and feeble in substance— He told me that he was not much accustomed to public speaking, and that he had spoken under much agitation— But he preserved perfect self command, and a clear and consistent course of argument, in answering the successive charges of Jenifer— It is a remarkable illustration of the composition of Congress, that in this Committee of nine members selected at random, every one has a good talent for public speaking— Mr Brown did not finish, but will take two, if not three more morning hours— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Dawson in the Chair on the Treasury Note Bill— King of Georgia made a speech of an opposition speech of an hour; followed by Bond of Ohio, till near 5. when the Committee rose for want of a Quorum, and the house adjourned— A man by the name of Carson, and Mr Hawley were here this Evening.
19. V. Thursday

Mr Hawley last Evening communicated to me his troubles— He has eight children to maintain—with himself and his wife ten—two women servants and a boy 13. with a Salary of 1500 dollars a year, and 275 dollars to pay for house-rent, he finds it very difficult to get along, and is sometimes ready to be disheartened— He wished to know whether he could not get from some of the public departments occasionally some writing for his daughters to do—and whether some thing could not be brought out of the Smithsonian fund which might benefit him— He has had his eye steadily upon this ever since the first notice of the existence of the Smithsonian bequest— Elizabeth Pierce was here this morning; and brought with her, a doctor’s certificate that her Sister Mrs Telfair was very sick and must be removed from the place where she now lodges—also a Letter from Mr Taliaferro to the Register Smith and his answer, respecting the funding of final certificates. She thought it quite favourable to their claim, and she asked me to speak a good word for them to Mr Craig, chairman of the Committee on revolutionary claims which I promised and did— But Mr Craig was not so easily propitiated—he referred me over to Mr Taliaferro— I took the first revised sheet of my Smithsonian report to the Globe office, and gave directions with regard to the printing of the rest— They afterwards sent me the second sheet which I revised and returned— At the house Mr A. V. Brown occupied the morning hour again in defence of the majority of the Committee of Elections to the great delight of his Colleagues Medill, Rives and Fisher and of the Chairman Campbell— He made as much of the case as he could, and used the weapon of ridicule to slur over the radical breach of faith of the majority of the Committee and of the House, in giving time to the parties to take evidence to ascertain who of them was lawfully elected, and then before the given day, without waiting for the evidence, and without hearing the parties, admitting one set of the claimants to the contested seats, under a forced report that they had a majority of the lawful votes.— At the expiration of the hour J. W. Jones called the orders of the day; Several executive communications were received, and among the rest a report from the Secretary of the Treasury on my Resolution calling for an account of the investments of public monies in State Stocks.— Committee of the whole on the Union Dawson in the Chair on the Treasury note Bill— Bond concluded his speech followed by Vanderpoel till 5. O’Clock when the Committee rose without a Quorum, and the House adjourned. There had been a Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures in the Morning—present Adams, Mitchell, Tillinghast, Slade, Dromgoole, Eastman, Davis— Absent Nisbett and Worthington— Evening visits from Christopher H. Morgan, and a Mr Sherwood from Albany.
20. V:15. Friday

At the meeting of the Committee of Manufactures yesterday it was agreed that the Chairman should report a bill, to increase the duties on silks, from ten to twenty per cent upon importations from beyond the Cape of Good Hope or Cape Horn, and from five to ten per Cent upon importations from within the Capes, and I was directed to prepare and submit to the Committee a report to accompany the Bill— The Memorial asking for the patronage of Congress to the silk Journal, finds no countenance in the Committee—the Article of silk covered buttons was added to Mr Tillinghasts Bill— This morning I was occupied in searching the documents relating to the Navy Pension fund, instead of those relating to the culture of silk which I ought perhaps to have preferred— At the House, Mr Aaron V. Brown consumed within a few minutes the morning hour; in concluding his speech on the New-Jersey election case, and when he sat down Watterson of Tennessee, right behind him, instantly started up, and moved the previous question— By what accident it happened I know not, but this motion failed to obtain a second by a vote oftoBotts then took the floor, but said he would yield it to any member of the majority of the Committee who might wish to address the house— Campbell said that he was willing now to rest the case where it was, and take the question—but whether he might have occasion to say any thing further on the subject might depend upon what Botts should say— Fisher said much the same— Botts asked Medill if he did not wish to speak further in his own justification— Jenifer had indirectly but explicitly and in a manner the more emphatic for being indirect charged him with lying— Medill said he should not notice any personal imputation upon himself unless it should come in a tangible form— Rives, saturated with mortification at the issue of his atchievement of last Saturday, consumed in supplication to the house to save him, his wife and children from the necessity of his fighting a duel with Jenifer, now said nothing— Botts began, and spoke about 5 minutes, when Jones, Chairman of the Ways and Means, called for the orders of the day, and moved a suspension of the rules to take up the Treasury Note Bill— Russell Chairman of the Committee of claims insisted upon adhering to the rule of preference for private business on Fridays and the motion to suspend failed for lack of two thirdstoCommittee of the whole on private business Davee in the Chair— Several bills were taken up and laid aside, till they came to a Bill for the relief of sufferers by the great fire at New-York which raised a snarling debate— Petrikin moved to strike out the enacting clause—lost by tellers 57 to 68.— Committee rose and reported sundry Bills— Turney moved to adjourn over to Monday— Lost by yeas and nays, adjourned at 5.— Seth A. Elliot of the Pension Office here this Evening.
21— V. Saturday.

Young Elliot is a son of the late William Elliot of this City, of manners rather obtrusive, whom I have for that reason always treated with reserve and even with coldness— His father was an English Unitarian Dissenter; a man of Science and of great merit, who died here very suddenly, two or three years since— This young man was educated as a printer, and is now a clerk in the pension Office— He brought me last Evening a pension certificate of 80 dollars a year for Mrs Mehitable Clark with a Letter from the Commissioner of Pensions— He brought also a Manuscript folio Volume of his fathers diary, and of which he said he had several others He read from it two extracts one of 3 and 4. March 1829. and one of 2. Jany 1833. in both of which he spoke favourably of me—and he said there were many others, expressive of stronger Sentiments— The minute under date of 2. Jany 1833. was that he called upon me and found me very busy— I told his Son now, what it was upon which I had then been busy— It was on the Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures reviewing President Jackson’s Message of 4. Decr 1832.— This young man talked with much bitterness of Mr Van Buren, and of Mr Paulding the present Secretary of the Navy— But I did not encourage him in this conversation— At the Houses this day there was some waiting for Mr Botts who was engaged with the Committee of elections until sent for— He then began his speech on the New Jersey election case; but in about half an hour by a call from John W. Jones for the orders of the day, the subject was again postponed. Jones moved as usual to suspend the rules to take up the Treasury Note Bill and again failed for lack of a vote of two thirds the yeas and nays being 103 to 68. The private Bills reported yesterday from the Committee of the whole were taken up and passed to a third reading without opposition, excepting the bill for the relief of the sufferers by fire in New-York, which was pertinaciously debated, and resisted tooth and nail by Petrikin and his gang; but finally passed to a third reading of yeas and nays— The question when the third reading should be came next—the call was for now— Turney moved this day week— The vote was for now; but by the chicanery of successive motions for adjournment the purpose was defeated, and by the Speaker’s want of energy, or his lukewarmness to the efficient adjustment of private claims the House adjourned between 3 and 4 without passing a single Bill— They ought to have passed at least 40— I spoke to Mr. Cushing about a meeting of the delegation from Massachusetts for consultation to which he assented. I called at Gadsby’s, and was informed that Mr Lawrence was this day, not so well.—
22. V. Sunday.

Walking to the Capitol this morning I met Mr Thomas L M’Kenny of Philadelphia coming from it finding that Mr Cookman whom he had gone there to hear was not to preach this day— I went and heard Dr Bates, who is a very good and sensible preacher—a relict of the last century— His text was from Acts 3.19. [“]Repent ye, therefore, and be converted, that your sins may be blotted out, when the times of refreshing shall come, from the presence of the Lord.”— Repentance and conversion, indispensable for salvation was the Doctors theme, and his discourse was Calvinism of the mildest character, for he divided professing Christian— 1. Those who performed all the Christian duties, and who needed no conversion and 2. Those who lived in the indulgence of any known sin— And to the latter Class, if any of such were present to hear him he gave solemn and emphatic warning that unless they should repent and be converted they would perish eternally— The auditory was thin— I called at Gadsby’s where the barkeeper informed me that Mr Lawrence was better. I returned the visit of Mr William Foster of Boston who is here with Mrs Ward, and his two daughters— I paid no other visit— After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church, where the Evening service for the 3d. Sunday in Lent was read by Mr Chauncy, and Mr Boyd preached, from Luke, 13.7. [“]Then said he unto the dresser of his vineyard, Behold, these three years I come, seeking fruit of this fig tree, and find none: cut it down; why cumbereth it the ground?” I met Miss Cutts with her little niece Mary, at the door of the Church, and they sat in my pew— The house was more full than I have seen it for years, but with at least five women to one man— Evening visit from Mr Binda, an Italian Gentleman whom we first met in England in 1817. He says at Lord Hollands, and at the Danish Minister Bourke’s— He says also that he dined with me in this City when I was President— I had lost all recollection of having ever seen him— He is married to one of the daughters of Thomas Sumter junr sometime Minister of the United States at the Court of Brazil, who on his return from that Country in 1822 was sometime here with his wife and a family of small children—one of these is Thomas D. Sumter, now one of the members of the House of Representatives from South-Carolina—another, the third daughter, is the wife of this Mr Binda, who has been several months here, with two daughters young children, who have become playmates of our Louisa. Mrs. Binda is an invalid, confined to her chamber, and has been for several years in bad health. Her mother Mrs Sumter is a french woman of noble family, whom Sumter married some forty years ago when he went to France, as Secretary of Legation to Robert R. Livingston—her name was Delage— Mr Binda came from Europe with his family last December; and leaving his wife and children here, went on to South-Carolina, whence he has but just returned— I read this day very little and that chiefly on politics.
23. V:30. Monday.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Mitchell, Nisbet, Dromgoole, Slade, Davis—absent Worthington, Tillinghast and Eastman— There was a large file of papers referred to the Committee last Monday—25 Memorials for a duty upon Silks; but Mr Tillinghast who presented the Bill for levying the duty on silks not being present that subject was passed over— There were several Memorials praying for a revision of the Tariff— The committee voted, the Chairman only dissenting, to ask to be discharged from the consideration of them, upon the principle that it is not yet time to revise the Tariff— I said I thought it was full time for taking it up; and that I would shortly ask the Committee to authorize me to offer to the House a Resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury to report at the next Session of Congress an entire revisal of the Tariff Mr Davis said he should be willing to vote for such a Resolution— The Committee acted upon several other references, and despatched more business than they have done any other day this Session. At the House a Motion was made to suspend the rules which devote this day to the presentation of Resolutions to take up that of Petitions— The first vote by rising was 77 to 36 more than two thirds, but no Quorum— I called for the yeas and nays and the vote then was 107 to 62 not quite two thirds, but so near it that while it was taking Clifford of Maine came to my seat and intreated me as my turn to be called for petitions would come before his, to offer only those of my petitions which would occasion no debate—postponing the others till next Monday which will be petition day again— I told him that it would give me the greatest pleasure to accommodate him; but that I had already once postponed the presentation of debatable petitions, at the instance of others, and could not in the consciencious discharge of my duties repeat the concession.— But the suspension failed, as did the motion of John W. Jones to suspend in order to take up the Treasury Note Bill;—by a vote of 112 to 67. The call for Resolutions commenced with Maine— Massachusetts soon followed— I offered 3. Resolutions— 1. a Call upon the President, for documents relating to the surrender of persons demanded by foreign Governments, or upon them by the United States in the case of the Schooner Plattsburg and others— Adopted without opposition, after Dawson had required a second reading of it before the vote was taken— 2. A Call upon the Secretary of the Navy for a statement of purchases and Sales of Navy Pension fund investments in State Stocks—adopted without a position 3. A declaratory resolution against the practice of pairing off— Objected to by Graves and Turney, and laid over 4. I called up, and modified the Resolution respecting the Africans of L’Amistad, adopted— The Call reached the State of Indiana; when upon an attempt of Rariden to introduce a Bill the House adjourned.
24. V:30. Tuesday
Nuit blanche.

I called this morning, first, at the pension office, and left with the Commissioner a Letter from my niece Mrs Treadway; concerning her claim to a Pension as the widow of Lieutenant Clark, and a Letter from Lewis and Pierce, with a second deposition of General Morgan Lewis, in support of the Pension claim at the War Office of Mrs Jennet Troup— Then at the War Office— The Secretary Poinsett, was absent, at his own house; I left with the chief Clerk, a minute to remind him of the application of Mr Samuel A. Turner of Scituate to be appointed one of the Visitors of the West-Point Academy next June— Then at the Navy Department where I left with the Secretary Paulding a Letter from Oliver Billings, concerning a claim of wages due to his grandson Cary, discharged last Summer as a boy from the naval school at New-York— Mr Paulding said he would refer the claim to Commodore Downes Commander of the Navy yard at Brooklyn— At the House, after an ineffectual motion of Rariden to suspend the rules to conclude the call of the States for Resolutions, the New-Jersey election report came up for the morning hour which was consumed without his concluding— Jones of the Ways and Means called for the orders of the day— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Dawson in the Chair— Trumbull made a speech against the Bill— Mr Black then moved that the Committee should rise to enable him to make the report from the Committee on the public printing which was to be made this day—but this motion was lost—the floor was then occupied successively by Evans, Underwood, Waddy Thompson, Monroe, Biddle, Habersham, Nisbet and Warren, all in opposition to the administration rather than to the Bill— Then about Sunset, Mr Barnard rose and said that he wished to present his views at large upon the bill; but being somewhat indisposed, and much exhausted he asked the indulgence of the house to postpone hearing him till to-morrow, and moved the Committee should rise with a view to the adjournment of the house— The men of Kinderhoek had decided that they would force the bill through—without answering any of the opposition Speeches, this Night— They refused to rise by a vote of tellers 53 to 90— Mr Barnard after a few remarks reasserting his inability from physical weakness to do justice to himself or to his constituents indisposed and exhausted as he was at that time moved again the Committee to rise—the count was again taken by tellers and was 10 ayes 85 noes—all the opposition members forbearing to vote and thus leaving the majority without a quorum.— The Committee were thus compelled to rise and report this fact to the house, and this first disclosed to both parties of the house the secret of the defensive strength of the minority—a strength the more impregnable as it consists in silence and precludes all disorder. The rage of the majority at this discovery was unbounded but it was impotent— After various efforts
Nuit blanche

to prove a quorum present by counting the members all ineffectual, the Committee rose and reported no Quorum Dromgoole lisping drunk moved a call of the house Rice Garland to adjourn— Albert Smith called for the yeas and nays on the motion to adjourn. 31 to 95. a Quorum voting—31 whigs afraid to abstain from voting, upon a call of yeas and nays— If only five of them had had the firmness to abstain from voting the majority would even then have been compelled to adjourn for want of a quorum— But a present quorum being ascertained the Speaker called the Chairman of the Committee of the whole again to the Chair— Barnard immediately renewed the motion that the Committee should rise, and the vote by tellers was 10 to 92. no Quorum— The majority finding themselves impotent for business, resorted to expedients— The first was a call to count the members present to prove a quorum present, which Dawson the Chairman at first decided he had no right to do, but for which he afterwards said he had found a precedent, and did; a number of the opposition members then left their Seats and went outside of the bar— Dawson counted and announced 107 members present— I never left my seat, but did not vote— Motions were made and Resolutions were offered by Vanderpoel, Beatty, and Crary to compel me to vote; but by previous contradictory decisions of the house, there was no time when any such motion could be entertained— The Committee were again compelled to rise and report no Quorum. Clifford moved to discharge the Committee of the whole from the consideration of the Bill; but as there was an appropriation in the Bill not acted upon in Committee this motion could not be entertained— About one O’Clock in the Morning a Call of the house was ordered by Yeas and Nays 91 to 71—so that there were then at least 162 members present, besides the Speaker and me, who did not vote— Yet at the first call of the names only 135 members answered— Noisy, confused and abortive negotiations for compromise commenced, to rise and report the Bill, with a pledge that there should be time allowed to debate the Bill in the house.— At the second call of the names 149 answered. 15 were excused. 62 were not excused— The doors were closed and the Sergeant at arms was despatched for the absentees— Duncan moved that I should be compelled to vote— Not in order— Beatty moved a resolution of censure upon me for not voting—not in order motions to suspend the call and to adjourn were multiplied and failed—22 members at one time and 14 at another were brought in, by the Sergeant at arms, called to account and excused or fined— At 8 in the Morning, the call was superseded, dilatory motions succeeded and failed. A second call of the house was ordered, and I now answered to my name— The call was suspended
and about 11. A.M Mr Barnard began his speech against the Bill, and kept the floor with some interruptions till near 2. P.M— He was followed a short explanatory speech by John W. Jones; then by Goggin of Virginia, in a speech of an hour against the Bill— Then after sundry motions for the Committee to rise, about 4. O’Clock P.M— Duncan of Ohio took the floor, and said he had, very few remarks to make upon the Bill, before the House, but he would make a long Speech on the Florida War— He spoke accordingly about half an hour during which the members were dropping and pairing off, till the quorum vanished again—the Committee rose to announce it— Three or four members of the two sides agreed, to finish the debate on the Bill to-morrow and at 5. O’Clock, a motion to adjourn was carried by yeas and nays 73 to 34— I walked home and found my family at dinner. From my breakfast yesterday morning till one this afternoon, 28 hours, I had fasted— My Carriage had been waiting for me four or five hours last evening till Thomas the Coachman could hold out no longer, and came home sick and faint— Jerry Leary remained at the Capitol nearly the whole night and brought me this morning a couple of small Sandwiches which I ate— But I felt during the whole process, neither hunger, thirst, not drowsiness— Fasting and quietude are the only way for me to pass through these ordeals— I retired to bed, about 9 O’Clock this Evening.
26. VI. Thursday

I rose at six this morning after nine hours of sound sleep, fully refreshed, and confirmed in the belief that the effective means of traversing these prolonged trials of madness and confusion the Nightly calls of the house is fasting— At ten this morning I attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams Mitchell, Tillinghast, Worthington, Eastman— Absent Dromgoole, Nisbet, Davis and Slade— I offered a Resolution, that the Chairman be directed to report to the House a Resolution requiring the Secretary of the Treasury to report to the House, in the first Session of the next Congres week of the next Session of Congress a plan for the entire revisal and amendment of the Tariff of duties on imported merchandise, to render it sufficient for the raising of a revenue to defray all the necessary expenditures of the Government of the United States, and for the protection and encouragement of the manufactures, and internal industry of this Country. This Resolution was discussed till the time for the meeting of the House. Worthington and Eastman did not directly oppose it. They were the minority of the meeting, and could not have prevented its adoption— But as Dromgoole and Nisbet were absent, I wished not to take the Committee by
